description.text:
■ design based on Flexy-Hand by Gyrobot. ■ FunMove redesign and modify to use Electronic Prosthetic Hand. ■ PREPARATION
  • 3D Printed FunMove Prosthetic Hand body
  • 1 (Arduino nano) or (Arduino Pro - mini)
  • 1 FSR(Pressure sensor)
  • 1 Servo Motor (MG945 or MG946R)
  • resister( 10K & 1K ) and capacitor ( 220uf )
  • battery ( 5V ) or ( USB Port )
    • FunMove_Arduino instruction : https://goo.gl/ImGJRc ● FunMove is a NPO in Korea.
    We believe that human's the simplest happiness come from physical activity.
    According to our belief, we are making prosthetic limb by utilizing Opensource hardware which are 3D printer and Arduino. ● You can see what we are doing from below.
  • Developing 3D printed electronic prosthetic limb
  • Donating 3D printed prosthetic limb to disabled
  • Donating Opensource education to disabled so that they can build and modify their own prosthetic limb.
  • Building up donation ecosystem. (Beneficiaries has to donate a prosthetic and opensource education to another disabled)
    • ○ website : http://www.fun-move.org
    ○ Facebook : https://goo.gl/Ofiq7I
    ○ Community : https://www.facebook.com/groups/FunMove/ ● 펀무브는 "인간은 신체활동을 통해 즐거움을 느낀다"라는 믿음으로 주변에 활동의 즐거움을 잃어버리신분들에게 즐거움을 찾아드리기위해
    3D 프린터, 아두이노 등 오픈소스 하드웨어를 활용해 3D 프린팅 전자 의수를 만들어 기부하는 비영리 단체입니다. ● 펀무브는 아래와 같이 활동하고있습니다.
  • 3D 프린팅 전자의수 개발
  • 장애인에게 전자의수 기부
  • 오픈소스 하드웨어 교육 제공

An attempt at a beveled twisted planetary gear bearing.  Inspired by Emmet.  
Check handedness.  Print 2 of the flat ones and 3 or more of the macaroons.  Assembly should be pretty obvious.

Looks like thingiverse has decide not to turn off "work-in-progress" automatically.  
I printed a working centimeter scale prototype.  Two copies of topbot2 and three or more of roller2.  Under heavy axial loads it does pretty well.  
six-18/18-six is a pair of bevel gears with a different tooth count ratio.  In principle, the tooth counts of the large and small gears should be coprime to so that wear is even, but I doubt any of the builds will see enough use for it to matter.

remixed_from.author: syvwlch
remixed_from.title: Printable Clock, Parametric Proof of Concept

description.text: Winner of the Pattywac Makerbot United Challenge for collaborative design: http://www.makerbot.com/blog/2011/05/16/pattywac-makerbot-united-challenge-winner/ Thank you team! :-) Video of the first ticking powered escapement mechanism: http://www.prototribe.net/vidplay/testjig2.html __WARNING Several bugs have been fixed since this release, and the current tip-of-the-spear for development is a simplified 2-gear clock with only minutes and seconds. Current development version to be found on git hub here: github.com/syvwlch/Printable-Clock-Project Current version of the 8-Gear Clock (revision D): http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8284 Current bleeding edge development version of the test jig: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8275 Current repository for the latest version of the clockwork library: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8155 Thanks to RustedRobot for his continued assistance debugging the clock! __WARNING This is both a derivative of the printable clock PoC, and of my escapement library: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7822 . The involute gear profiles are from the MCAD library. (EDIT: The clock got a mention by Cory Doctorow on boing boing! http://www.boingboing.net/2011/04/23/model-files-for-a-wo.html ) I cleaned up the code so it would render faster, moved all the gear work into the library, and created a laidOutToPrint() module to facilitate creating the STLs of the individual parts. I included an optional print volume visualizer, so you can check every part doesn't exceed the printer's capabilities. The assembled() module is still fully animate-able, and I've added colors to help see if everything meshes properly. The clock itself now has clip-on hands, front & back frames, and most importantly, I switched to a different set of gear ratios (3.2, 3, 2.5 & 2.5) which allows for bigger shafts by keeping the ratios small. Assuming an 80x80x80mm printing volume, you now have a bit more than 12mm (almost half an inch!) available for the overall diameter of the shaft, the two sleeves that slide over it and the necessary clearances. I think this configuration is close to final, except for the escapement, which will need fine-tuning... but without re-printing the rest of the clock.

Print one of each STL file, or fiddle with the script, check your work with assembled(), and then generate a new STL for each part with laidOutToPrint(), and print those.  
The current configuration requires four shafts to slip the sleeved gears over, outer diameter 2mm with a clearance of half a millimeter either side. I suspect it might be possible to simply screw an M3 bolt into each end of the longest sleeves and to widen the holes in the frames a tad.  
I'm unfortunately rather sure the escapement won't work properly as is, but it would be nice to know if the rest of the clock does, i.e. if you can turn the escapement wheel, and have the gear train run smoothly and the three hands spin around.  
I'll be working on the escapement next, but whatever I come up with in that regard should be backwards compatible with this design, with only the need to print a new escapement wheel, escapement and pendulum.

comments.text: It would be nice if the pendulum was in parts... like, have a way to attach the weight using a dowel and a set screw or something.... that would get us closer to an adjustable pendulum without making it harder to print...  does the weight of the pendulum matter? pockets for pennies? idunno.
comments.author: ssd

comments.text: Weight does not matter per se for the period, which is set by the distance between the axis of rotation and the pendulum's center of gravity... So by placing a heavy weight at the swinging end, you keep the overall length shorter.
comments.author: ssd

comments.text: The pendulum period follows the square of the length, by the way, so if we introduce a 2:1 gear between the escapement and the second's hand, the pendulum would be 1/4 the length, or 25cm. Use a 3:1 gear and it would 1/9 the length, or 11 cm.
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: Since I'm starting to get some really valuable feedback from Makers that have printed and assembled this Thing, I figured I would say thank you by entering it in the MakerbotUnited challenge (Original idea by Sir MakeALot) and opening up a comment thread for these contributors to speak up.

comments.text: I left the clearance parameter for the involute_gear MCAD library as a top-level parameter, and that would be the best way to fix that, rather than changing the axis separation (too many knock-on effects). Backlash is also adjustable.
comments.author: Unknown

comments.text: That sounds right. I'm trying a test where I reprint the endplates using scale of 1.02 (one gripe of rep-g is not good measurement tool).
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: Actually, yeah, that's the best way to fix it given the mass of gears you already have lying on the work bench. :-)
comments.author: Unknown

comments.text: So, scaling by 1.03 was perfect dead on for the 2 end plates. The next issue. Without changing to some ball bearings, I don't think we can get this to work driving by a weight system. From the minutes hand (from the gear itself) is about the limit of where I could spin mine for the escapement to work. There is just too much friction and binding to work as a "real" clock driven from the hours drum. Mine is very free spinning,just as the gear ratio increases-so does the torque required due to friction. It's a beautiful work of art and demonstrates the possibities of what can be done. This is not to say it won't work as a demonstration clock. We just won't get days of operation like a real clock would (unless you have a really tall elevator shaft to drop the weight in). Also, for those gettting the bright idea for weights and pulleys, there is a limit to how much weight we could pull and then, it still binds on the critical 3 concentric shafts (really part of the problem). We need to reduce friction caused by heavy side load on shafts, drive it from someplace other than the hours gear directly. Some creative pockets to allow gears to be supported on the longer shafts by ball bearings on both sides would do wonders. The space is there-and I know I've seen bearings in RC cars with large inner diameters and ony slightly larger outers that would work.
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: Interesting... we could drive if off the escapement by putting the drum there, but then yeah, we'd only get a minute of drive per winding of the string! Still, a valuable step forward if it gets us to a ticking clock! Halfway there would be to drive if off the minute gear... that could get us a few hours' worth of run-time, enough to gauge accuracy. :-)
comments.author: Unknown

comments.text: I add that all the gear modules, pinionWheel(), pinionDrum() and pinionEscapementWheel(), have parametric hubs for height, bore diameter and wall thickness, and so fitting a bearing in there should not be too hard.
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: Further thought on the whole arrangement. While the current design is compact, the issue is massive friction from plastic on plastic. Real clocks also don't use this design and a simple change making each gear ride on the metal shafting directly will reduce friction. I can try a very simple experiment where I use long 3mm shafts, break the current long plastic shafts on the gears so that they become indepedent. Also, the front and back plates really need to get tied together and maintain a square relationship-but we knew that anyway for the escapement. In all, its very possible. Also, I was thinking a 5th shaft and gear for the actual tension drum to drive the clock.
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: Yeah, friction is clearly a problem, altho now that we know I got the minute-hour gearing wrong, it's going to take 5 times less power to drive the whole train. Silly me. :-)
comments.author: Unknown

comments.text: I think I had a minor epiphany on the topic of driving the gears directly on the metal shafts. With the exception of the nested hour/minute/seconds gears, the remainder could work in the original configuration. I'd misread syvwich's original BOM and the reference to 8 M2 screws and used 4 50MM M3 screws with nylock nuts. With that length of screw it eliminates the need for the narrow shafted gears to continue through the gear above. It should be possible to shorten the length of the narrow shaft to provide shelf for the gear above to rest on, while shrinking the larger diameter shafted gears back down to fit the M2 or M3 screw!
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: Yup, that would certainly work, and eliminate most of plastic on plastic friction from 3 of the 4 stacks. I think that is an important enough change, along with the 60/12 gaffe-fix, to warrant a new release. Might be nice if I included the escapement shaft in the frame this time, too.
comments.author: rustedrobot

comments.text: One other thing that i've done on the latest test of the 12x60 scad file is add an X cross brace to the front and back frames (corner to corner). It will hide a bit of the pretty gearing, but should add rigidity to the structure. I'm not sure it wil be needed in the new release (or maybe only on the back?) but figured it was worth a try.
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: That is another great idea. :-)

comments.text: Ok, so "Pro" tips if you want this to work. Use a heated build platform (ABP belts are not flat enough). Wipe down your HBP when cool with acetone (only when cool) to remove any fingerprints since any curling at an edge will ruin the print. Level your platform with extreme precision.
comments.author: Unknown

comments.text: Awesome! Thanks for taking the time and plastic to make this happen. :-)
comments.author: Unknown

comments.text: I've generally found that thicker parts stay hot and pliable longer and with more layers you end up with a greater strength pulling at the corners. Thinner pieces don't have as much time to do the pulling before they cool. I've had 0.5" thick pieces pull the kapton tape and the aluminium heat spreader off the heater pcb at times. Active cooling may help.
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: Actually make that 0.75" thick pieces. Just went and measured.
comments.author: rustedrobot

comments.text: Aha... Interesting. So thinner parts actually warp less?
comments.author: rustedrobot

comments.text: I can't speak for everyone, but for me that seems to be the case.
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: This is going to be one of those tradeoff situations. What I was getting at is the smaller pinions could be thicker to accomodate warpage of the larger gear teeth, but making longer shafts is a problem too. Right now, it seems it's going to work fine (I'm on the third gear and al shafts and everything fit inside each other perfectly. I guess what I'm getting at is this is the ultimate "calibration" print. Find out how god your printer really is by trying to print part 10 clock escapement, followed by a gear  such as part 9. If those go well, you can easily just print the rest.
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: Can't wait to see the pictures and find out if the gear train works without needing too much torque... Again, thanks for printing this out. :-)

side (6 in total). It's thicker than the original in order to hold 1kg of filament. Use M3x6 (15pcs.) countersink screw, only put 2 screws on each wing and leave the

I designed this handle in Solidworks 2014. The font used is called "Brothers" and is the font used by Ballast Point Brewery. I think it's a really sexy font. The handle features a 3/8"-16 brass threaded insert where it threads onto the tap. The insert was actually designed for wood (oops) and doesn't thread into plastic very well. I tried heating it up, no dice. I ended up just making the hole it threads into only about .010" smaller than the major diameter of the threads. Very little thread engagement, but it's not exactly a high-risk application.
The handle is printed in black PLA with .2mm layer height, 30% infill. It was printed on my Printrbot Simple Metal. Took about 3 hours to print, if I recall correctly. The exact threaded inserts can be found on mcmaster.com (what can't be?)

This is a case for the LCR-T4 variant of the quite wonderful universal transistor and component tester developed by Markus Frejek, and later Karl-Heinz Kübbeler. A full description of the project is available here: http://mikrocontroller.net/articles/AVR_Transistortester This case fits the variant with graphical display sold on Ebay and elsewhere called LCR-T4. The case includes a compartment for the battery, and gives access to the surface mount component test area. The pinout for the 14 pin ZIF test socket is printed on the case, for reference. Note that there are several different variants of this tester in the market. This case is only designed to fit the LCR-T4. You need four M3x15 countersunk screws for assembling the top and bottom sections. Note that the PCB for this case is the T4. The T4 is somewhat similar to the T3 PCB, but it is not the same, and does not fit the same case. There are also other variants out there. Please examine the pictures of the PCB carefully to make sure you have the right PCB before you start your print. A case for the T3 is available here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:694790 Another case are here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1580922 and here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1920077 A case for a variant with alphanumeric display is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:641003 Note: The variant glcd_tester_lcr_t4_extra has room for a PCB that is up to 2 mm larger on the righthand side. Some versions of the T4 seems to have this larger PCB. This variant will also work with the original PCB. Note that this variant is not tested (yet).
Should print without support, and with not too much cleanup. If warping is an issue, you may consider adding a brim. The top section should be printed upside-down.

This isn't a printable item, but I figured I'd post it here anyway since it's somewhat relevant and I've got a 3D drawing of the piece to show. Might come in handy if you have the requisite tooling to make this part. I came up with this design by putting together some elements of E3Dv6's heat break (ultra-thin heat transition zone with 0.4mm walls) and Jetguy's brass nut trick, which helps conduct heat from just above the transition zone to the aluminium cooling bar.  
Flashforge Creators are Chinese clones of the Makerbot Replicator 1 Dual but with an incompatible aluminium cooling bar, which means you can't use a standard M6 threaded heat break as most Reprap hotends use. Also, the stock heat break has a Teflon liner which excludes you from printing with any of the higher temperature materials like Nylon. Technically, you shouldn't be printing ABS either, but I guess that's borderline.  
This piece is a drawing of the replacement heat break I machined out of a stainless steel half-threaded screw.

Materials required:

  • M6 Stainless steel screw (or 6mm stainless steel cylinder if you want to do your own threading) with at least 14mm smooth shank and 13mm thread. Possibly a bit more, because you need to saw off the head and smooth both the top and bottom.

  • M6 brass nut
    • Steps:
  • Behead the screw, and smooth both sides to get a nice perpendicular edge.
  • Drill a bore of 2mm through the center of the screw.
  • Taper the edge of the threaded portion of the screw until you get an 0.4mm wall.
  • Thin a 2mm-long section in the middle of the threaded portion until its outer diameter is 2.2-2.4mm, leaving exactly 6mm to the edge of the threaded side.
  • Countersink the bore at the smooth end.
  • Optionally polish the bore.
  • Screw the brass nut all the way in, then back out by half a turn.
  • Assemble the hotend with this heat break in place, then mount onto the cooling bar, pushing the heat break up until the brass nut touches the cooling bar.
  • Tighten the brass nut against the cooling bar for better thermal contact, and so that it doesn't shake loose during print.\
  • Print! You may or may not need to use the canola oil trick depending on how well you drilled/polished the bore, but at least you now have an all-metal hotend on the Flashforge that'll print PLA for the price of a stainless steel screw.

author: NickyP

description.text:
Updated October 6, 2014: A front-accessible adjustable Z endstop.
Updated July 10, 2013: Made the clips longer by default.
.
This is my first use of a simple concept, to mount parts on the printer using clips that span two rigid points, either from the back of the frame to the front the M8 smooth rod, or between two rods. Parts built this way should be more secure, require no extra hardware, be easy to add/remove, and complement the i3 design.
.
The first revision only included a Z endstop mount. It worked so well I've added a Y endstop mount that attaches to two bed rods. These are my current results. You may need to tune the SCAD file to get the best fit for your machine. Earlier revisions made the clips a little too short by default.
.
By default these mounts are set up to hold 20mm x 10.5mm x 6mm endstops. The Z endstop is aligned lengthwise between the rod and the frame. They can be modified to accept any size endstop that will fit in the space, or even outside it with some extra hacking.
.
Adjustable Z Endstop Holder
Z endstop adjusters tend to be ugly and at hard-to-reach angles, so I wanted to make something easy to reach from the front. The result here uses a screw through a block that translates front-back motion into up-down motion to move the endstop holder itself on the rod and frame. By default the motion range is 2.5mm, but this can be tuned in the SCAD file.

These mounts should work well in either PLA or ABS with any layer height. Once the SCAD parameters are tuned well for your printer the clips should be pretty tight and won't move at all. If your Z endstop is reliable you can try using the plain Z endstop holder to set-and-forget your endstop. Personally, I prefer the adjustable Z endstop holder.
.
Assembly
The bottom of each endstop holder is open to allow the connectors to pass through. Disconnect the endstop, run its wires through the bottom of the mount, and press-fit the endstop into the mount as far as it will go.
.
It's a little tricky to get the Z home set at first. I find it helps to push in the frame end of the clip but leave the rod end loose so it will move up and down more easily. Once the Z looks good, clip the rod end to secure the endstop.
.
For the adjustable Z endstop:
  • Put a nut into the trap inside the slider block.
  • Put the slider block into the adjuster with the square hole at the top.
  • Put an M3 screw through the whole block and tighten all the way
  • Put 2x M3 nuts on the end of the screw to fix it in place
  • Clip the endstop holder on first, find a good height
  • Clip the adjuster onto the frame, fitting the tab into the slot
  • Optional: Secure the adjuster with a screw or glue
    .
    Customization
    The default parameters in the SCAD and STL files are set up for my Prusa i3 built with the Prusa i3 Laser Cut Frame and Braces by sgraber. They should be easy to rework for your particular i3, even if it's a mini. The important parameters are rod_frame_gap, y_rods_gap, and frame_thickness. Set the rod_frame_gap to the space between the M8 rod and your frame, easily measured with a caliper. Do the same with y_rods_gap, taking the space between the rods as a rough guideline. You can shave off ~1mm here for a tighter mount. Set frame_thickness to the thickness of your i3 frame.

A customizable shoe. Makes a pair of wedges, 2D soles, or high heels. Length, width and shape are customizable.  
Options include a beveled tip, holes for sandal straps, and a bore for adding a structural screw into the heel (to counteract the sheer forces that might split the layers of filament when printed on an FFF printer - resulting in a trip which might cause injury to the nerdy fashionista*).   
If you want any features, ask in the comments. Features under contemplation are a closed toe and a heel support.  
*Or fashionisto. I can imagine that there is at least one drag queen with a 3D printer who cant find size 14 high heels.  
EDIT (24 AUG 2015): User Neon22 pointed to an error in which the options on the 2nd tab wouldn't work. These have been corrected.

Shoe Assembly Instructions
  • Trace your foot with a thick sock on.
  • Take the measurements needed by the program, and choose an appropriate screw.
  • Input the parameters in the program
  • Generate an STL file (because of how the file is generated, it wont look right on preview in either OpenSCAD or Customizer, this might change with newer versions of the language).
  • Print the shoes (although I doubt most shoes will fit on most printers).
  • Check that the shoes are the right size, that the straps fit, and the screws fit in the holes.
  • (if you are really lucky you can skip this step) Throw out your 8 hour print, adjust parameters and repeat steps 5 and 6.
  • Use velcro or ribbon to create strap.
  • The bottom of the heel hole is one quarter of the sole thickness above the bottom. Countersink a hole for the head of the screw based on this information and the screw length.
  • Screw the screw into the heel hole. Fill The countersink bore with epoxy or joint compound or some other gap filler.
  • (optional) create pads for your shoes or buy inserts. Glue padding to the shoes.
  • Affix straps.
  • Strut...a lot.
  • (optional) Remember that they make Red PETE filament, and now you really can have ruby slippers.

title: Auto belt tightener for x axis

description.text:
I was building my huxley (it's still not running) and I noticed that tightening the belts was not so easy. too loose and it skipped and too tight and it binds and sometimes it would not run. so I downloaded some stl files from Techzone and modified them. here is the first one, the X axis module. I hope it is useful and when some one prints one and its not to expensive you can send me one so I can see if im doing things right, or if I have to modify it, thanks.
that part should work with most of the printers out there.
z is next and y later

• print part
  • place spring (fairly stout spring) on the nub of the x module.
  • place the other end of the spring on small part with the slotted hole.
  • slide the small piece in the groove of the x module.
  • place a 3mm bolt in the slotted piece.
  • slide it in the x module groove.
  • put bolt through hole. and (do not tighten down all the way.
    let the spring do the work.

comments.text:
Make sure your layers are as thin as possible. Use Slic3r, CURA will ignore anything it thinks is too small, even if your printer can handle it. In Slic3r, you can also set shell thickness and view it like repiter's display for paths. Set thinner or thicker and check how it looks generally a thinner outter edge will make a sharper edge. Set infill to solid and measure your filament with a caliper in several places along 1-2 meters of filament. Add them together and decide by number of measurements to get an average. .01mm is enough to cause under extrusion which you will see in transparent filament like Tglase, with its reflective properties... measuring down to 3 decimal places, if your slicer supports it, is enough to get exact extrusion. Make sure you get quality filament with a consistent diameter. Some cheap ones are bad about inconsistent diameters. Also make sure you orient it properly for its shape, sideways is the best way to get a sharp edge, use support and turn it up as high as you're comfortable. If you have HIPS filament (disolvable), you can turn on support shells and make solid surfaces on the top of support structures, that you can then disolve away and get perfect bridges and overhangs. Let me know if you have any questions about Slic3r, it's difficult to learn. Also make sure you get the newest version. The developer version (not the stable one). It has a lot of awsome things that regular slic3r doesnt. It will crash frequently on big models, it's a result of the GUI. That's ok, it will usually save any settings, just reopen and do the same thing, but give it a second to process. If you give it time, it won't crash, so keep that in mind. Its my favorite slicer, enough that I don't care about any crashes, it does an incredible job. I only use CURA when I have a large model and no bridges (CURA doesn't support bridging speeds in its current version). I'll be here, or email me at [email protected]
Happy to help.
comments.author: Dominick

title: Filament Cleaner / Sweeper for the M3D Micro

description.text:
This is a small neat filament cleaner that is sculpted to sit well on the top of the M3D Micro's print head. The small amount of drag it induces is inline with the filament feed, so that doesn't drag at the head as it moves.  
Just cut a cube of foam a little larger than the cleaner, and press it in.  
The first time you use it, cut the filament at an angle so that it is pointed, and use that to bore a hole through the foam.  
The filament enters the cube on the side that has no cutout, and the cutout sits around the cable that exits the Micro's print head.

There are two versions of the STL. I suggest you print the scaffolded version without support switched on and then remove the scaffolding with needle-nosed pliers or similar.  
Cut a cube of foam a little larger than the cleaner, and press it in.  
The first time you use it, cut the filament at an angle so that it is pointed, and use that to bore a hole through the foam.  
The filament enters the cube on the side that has no cutout, and the cutout sits around the cable that exits the Micro's print head.

comments.text: If you don't want to use support, try printing this on its corner at 45°. Use a small brim or raft if you need to, but overall it should yield good results as most printers have no issue printing at 45° without support.

description.text:
I purchased a King Canada miniature metal lathe which came with a ton of accessories, including spare gears which I will eventually print instead of purchase.  
The most common used tools including a cutting bit needed to be stored close by. So I made these 3 holders that when put side by side will store all the accessories neatly and within reach.  
Update: Made another holder for a chuck and the point that came with the lathe.

I used doublesided tape, but something that has strong adhesion. The chuck grippers are a little heavier. So I made that part twice as thich so I can put more tape on it. Its about 50mm thick where the other two are 25mm thick.  
I stuck them closer to the chuck on the back so as not to vibrate as much since the sheet metal is held together closer to the chuck and doesn't move as much in that location.  
There isn't any need for support. Just make sure you print the LatheTools part with the wide square opening up since it tapers towards the bottom. thats about it really.

title: Parametric knob for attaching camera to $14 Steadicam

description.text: Johnny Chung Lee published a great design for a $14 Steadicam (http://littlegreatideas.com/stabilizer/diy/). However, the camera attachment relies on a wing nut and a washer, so when the camera is not attached, the washer is loose, and you have to flip the wing nut to hold it in place. I figured I could make a plastic knob that fits around a nut, and fills the role of both the wing nut and the washer, thus keeping things simpler. I decided to try out OpenSCAD to do this, and it turned out to be perfect. It's so easy to change things that I have included a file for a 1/4 inch screw, which fits most cameras, and another version for a 3/8 inch screw, which allows attaching alternative tripod heads. This is a generally useful piece for attaching cameras to all sorts of home-made camera mounts.

Print out the size that you want (1/4 inch or 3/8 inch), and pop an appropriate-size nut in the opening. I find it works well to put the nut in before the piece has cooled down, then as it shrinks it is held in place really firmly. Of course, you can just glue it in place.
I also find it useful to attach a neoprene washer to the top of the thing, to provide even pressure to the camera base.
To use it, loosen the knob, ie. turn it so that it goes away from the end of the bolt. Thread the camera on to the bolt, and point it in the direction you want. Tighten the knob against the base of the camera to hold it in place.

description.text:
Updated the LCD to a GLCD display, and needed a case for this Geeetech rectangular GLCD. I looked but could not find anything suitable to the way i wanted to mount it. This object was a one off, and it DOES have issues. There are NO NUT POCKETS in the front lid and i just "inserted" a set of nuts into the posts in the lid. ( McGyver'd it ) I could have drilled through the front also, but chose not to. The support structure in the back has a tendency to loosen up. The SDHC holder slot is too tight and has to be trimmed. However it was good enough for me, as it eases clearances for the spool holder, despite being a lousy print.
Treat this as a work in progress.

The base triangle replaces the back corner triangle on the mendelmax 1.5 frame. I DID have to "make a hole" in the case back for access to the jumper for the backlight on the GLCD board. ( again it is a work in progress )

Here is a simple dock made from acrylic, machine screws, and an existing iPhone/iPod cable. It is made of four slices of 1/4â€³ acrylic (actual width 0.22â€³). The top two slices have an oval opening just snug enough to fit the ipod connector and keep it in place with friction. The third slice has a channel for the cable to escape out the back, and the bottom slice keeps the cable from falling out and provides some pushback when the iphone is inserted. Itâ€™s held together by four 1â€³ 2-56 machine screws with nuts. I was a little concerned with the nuts scratching the table, so Iâ€™ve since added little hot glue feet to the bottom of each nut. I didnâ€™t add an additional layer at the top to provide lateral support of the iphone because I didnâ€™t have long enough screws. And besides, it doesnâ€™t seem to need it. If I get longer screws, I might make one that has the extra layer, which would also make the dock bigger, to encompass the bottom of the iPhone. And that would be good because it adds more mass to the dock, making it more stable. Also, see: http://todbot.com/blog/2009/07/15/quickie-laser-cut-iphoneipod-dock/

• Laser cut the pattern in the .svg (or .eps or .cdr) file.
  • Push iPod cable into top two slices, friction-fitting them in.
  • Attach cable channel slice, running cable out the back.
  • Add bottom slice, then use 1" 2-56 machine screws & nuts to secure it all.

description.text:
Printable spool equivalent in size to MakerBot Filament Spool. I only have one spool and the rest of my filament is a pain in the neck.
Until I have used this up, I need a filament spool or two that fit on Charles Pax's MakerBot Filament Spool Holder. I'm sure there are plenty of good spools out on Thingiverse already, and I'm sure I should reference half of them as inspirational to this one. I couldn't find one that was a direct replacement for the MakerBot spool, which is what I wanted. I've posted it in-case someone else is pulling their hair out trying to manage with just one, like me... The filament guide is just a quick hack, but it also works as an adjustable break and slides onto the top of the ToM. I should really have updated the spool holder to include the filament guide.

The printed parts go together nicely :) each is an interference fit, with the printed serrations adding a comforting "ratchet" noise as you push them together. A couple of the edge joints needed a squeeze with a pair of pliers. Print:
1 core
16 arms (4 sets)
16 edges (4 sets) with or without holes?
Firmly push them together and then load with filament
(Crank handle at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8082) I've printed some parts raft-less, this is by far the easiest and quickest, you will need to trim a tiny piece of filament from the bottom layer in the "V" on the dovetails. The layer that was attached to the bed spreads a little. Once you've gone all the way round, the "wheel" is a little stressed (a mm or so too long for its circumference because of all the joint tolerances). I placed the finished spool on its side on a sheet of aluminium foil on the cooker hob/stove hot-plate for a few minutes each side. This released all the stresses and I had nice flat spool. Added a bit of shine too :) I note that if you insert the raft-less pieces top-side to top-side, they go in much more easily. Now attach to your MakerBot Filament Spool Holder
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7105 Use until all your non-spooled filament is exhausted.

comments.text: Is that orange thin some sort of fan, it looks intriguing.
comments.author: Bluemetal

comments.text: Yes. It is my half-baked former CPU fan thing. The idea is to create a ring of air flow around the nozzle. There is a bunch of small holes drilled on that bottom ring pointing at the tip of the nozzle. I made the wall too thin on it so I used tape to cover the gaps. Its composed of two elements (glued with MEK) and still experimental. You can see the back side on the picture below. I have not finished it so have not posted the .skp and .stl files. The main idea was to get the air to the plastic and not to the body of the nozzle without interfering with the printing process. Clearly a work in progress (lack of progress that is)!

I have this coathanger with plastic hooks that are all breaking over time. Now with my 3D printer I can print replacement hooks! There was still a problem though. The printed hooks break rather easily. This is now fixed by printing the hooks with a hole in the middle, in which a steel nail is fitted! Drawn with BricsCAD.

I printed hooks in PLA and in ABS, both work fine. Definitely needs a raft, else the part will fall down while printing. Printed at 0.1mm layer thickness and 30% infill.  
After printing, you can stick a nail into it. The nails I used are 65 mm long and have 2.8 mm diameter.

This is a functional replacement Stylus for the New 3DS XL that actually fits in the slot to hold one. I couldn't find another one that actually fit it, so this came in pretty handy, as I've already lost the original.

For best results, or at least for me, spiralize the outer contour, and use a heat source of some kind, for me it was a lighter, to smooth the sharp tip at the end to keep it from scratching your screen.

description.text: something

This is my second design of FPV googles. Inside is a 4.3 inch LCD which i bought from ebay (car backup camera)
The size of the display is 122x72x15mm
http://www.ebay.ch/itm/4-3-LCD-TFT-Auto-KFZ-MONITOR-DISPLAY-f-Ruckfahrkamera-/260797997589?pt=LH_DefaultDomain_77&hash=item3cb8c5a215 The size of the lens i used is 135x95mm (http://www.3dlens.com/shop/pocket-fresnel-magnifier.php) The Frame is fully modular. The middle part comes in different lenghts. Print the front frame and the back frame first.
Then look inside and measure the distance you can see the picture the best possible way. After that choose the right middle frame piece. the number in the file name is the lenght of the middle frame. If you need some lenght what I've not uploaded, give me a shout and i will upload it. They really work :-) Weighs 310g Parts used: 1 LCD car backup display -> Ebay
1 Fresnel lens -> http://www.3dlens.com

This is essentially the same design as my popular Replicator 2 Mk8 extruder upgrade http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:42250 its just been adjusted to fit the geometry of the Replicator 2X - so the instructions are basically the same. You will just need to use one of the long countersunk 3M screws from the 2X extruder to mount the arm, you also re-use the bearings, all you need is a countersunk M3 x 10mm and a countersunk M4 x 15 for each extruder.
I have added a filament feed tube connector to the top of the arm, and a few other requested refinements.

Print, install and enjoy!  
I have uploaded Lefthand (L) and Righthand versions.

description.text: I made this as a design for a friend that had seen something similar last Halloween but didn't think to buy it then. I thought it'd be a fun challenge to test my modeling abilities to make a screw in base that was fully printable, so I designed this.

This is my redesign of mechanical parts used to build a Wallmount Polar Drawbot . I built mine collecting and mixing various information I found available on the web. The electronics and firmware comes from Dan Royer's "Makelangelo project" (Makelangelo SOFTWARE - Makelangelo FIRMWARE ) using V1 version of Adafruit motor shield but I used an DK Electronics motor shield I made several test trials using parts found ready around many projects, but none seem to match the requirements I would like to obtain. So I completely redesign all parts. Following several tests I developed 3 kind of pulley: one is to be used for smooth cords and others for synchronous trasmission made with ball chains. 3 types of ball chain can be used: Ø 3,2 mm all metal chain with pitch of 4 mm , Ø4,4 mm plastic ball and cord with pitch 6 mm, Ø4,4 mm plastic ball and cord with pitch 12 mm They can be used interchangeably, just remember to change pulley diameter in the machine setup or you obtain unaspected results. Also the overall dimensions like stepper motors interaxes or drawing area can be changed at your convenience (remember also to change them in setup) As a counterweight I used some exhausted "D" type batteries and for that I made several kind of holder to hang them. For mechanical parts I was also inspired from some photos of Kongorilla on Flickr https://www.flickr.com/photos/[email protected]/

New
I post some images on Flickr here: https://www.flickr.com/photos/[email protected]/sets/72157652579199386

12/08/15
added a video of drawbot in action at:
https://youtu.be/hQ8BQ0GsLiE in the next month I think I'll develop an MK2 version

new timelapse video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=30_FnJPDODY

update 19/09/15
video assembly instructions:https://youtu.be/bMyd1Vm-Nrk
In trasmission gears and the pen fixing, I used captive nuts so remember to pause the gcode and insert the nut as explained in my previous things

comments.text:
Hi all,
i'm facing some trouble with the software.
I'm currently using the software that is suggested in the makelangelo's site, for the makelangelo v 2.5, i guess.
Anyway, sometimes something goes wrong and the print stops without errors, the motor shield isn't hot, and the colored lines (the ones that highlight the planned movements) stop too.
I think that it's a problem in the Java software, not in the firmware, so i've searched for updates and i've found this: https://www.marginallyclever.com/2016/02/makelangelo-7-3-1/
New host software, that needs the last firmware version.
The problem with this new version is related to the limit switches.
Even if i've commented the line which is supposed to define the behavior of the drawbot, when i connect the machine it will move forever, i guess searching for the limit switches (but i'm not sure of that).
Does anyone have had experience with that?
One option is to remove this function.
Another option is to add the switches and actually use this function. I'm using a L293D shield V1, and there are several I/O available.
Is not a problem to add some pins on the shield, i just don't know how this switches are supposed to work (NC, NO, with a pullup resistor, ecc).
I'll try to gather further informations...
comments.author: daysleeper

comments.text: The version this Thing recommends has limit switches turned off by default, but it sounds like you have them turned on. The firmware (Arduino sketch) should have an option for using or not using limit switches. You should be able to turn that option off by commenting out the appropriate line, and then it will not search for a limit. If it is searching for home even with limit switches disabled, then it is a bug in the firmware and you can report it here.
comments.author: daysleeper

comments.text: The electronics aren't very well covered here or where the drawbot is inspired from, unfortunately. You'll need two stepper motors, a servo, an Arduino Uno (or Uno shield compatible, like a Mega), and a motor driver shield like this one. Then you can download the software from http://www.makelangelo.com/ . I'm using the instructions at http://learn.marginallyclever.com/index.php/Makelangelo_2.5.2 for mine. comments.text:
Salve, mi spiace per i problemi, e capisco la frustrazione che si prova dopo infiniti tentativi andati a vuoto. A me è successo praticamente per ogni progetto che implicava dell'elettronica visto che non è proprio il mio campo. A volte funziona anche solo mollare tutto, farci una dormita e riprendere la lotta a mente fresca (si fa per dire perchè il mio tempo libero va dalle 22 alle 2 di notte) Ma mi sembra che non sia questo il caso visto che pare la cosa dura da più giorni. Io sono due settimane che lotto con un braccio robotico derivato dal MeArm di cui ho dignitosamente ridefinito la parte meccanica ma appena cerco di gestire più servo contemporaneamente comincia a saltare come un canguro impazzito. Sono passato attraverso innumerevoli sketch e librerie dedicate oltre che a potenziometri o condensatori di tutte le taglie. Mi sà che ho magicamente risolto questa sera attrezzandomi con una scheda pololu dedicata a gestire i servo. Forse ho divagato un po ma era per cercare di tirarti su il morale. Sinceramente con gli elementi che hai fornito non saprei molto come aiutarti. Come ho accennato i componenti meccanici che ho disegnato sono universali, nel senso che tutte le versioni di drawbot polari meccanicamente si equivalgono la differenza la fanno poi con il software e l'elettronica. Io inizialmente volevo partire dal Polargraph (euphy) ma ha l'elettronica dedicata e ho ripiegato sul Makelangelo che usava un semplice arduino con una shield per i motori di facile reperibilità.
Un problema potrebbe essere quello di non avere installato java sul computer ma se mi dici che parte il makelangelo.jar allora non è questo il problema. Rimarrebbe solo la possibilità (penso) che non hai detto ad arduino di caricare le librerie amf (per lo shield dk sono quelle della V1 e non dell'ultima v2 per una adafruit originale) nello sketch prima di trasferirlo all' arduino UNO - mettere la cartella AFMotor drawbot nel percorso librerie di arduino - e nello sketch firmware_ams.ino - #define MOTHERBOARD 1 // Adafruit Motor Shield 1
comments.author: brasso

description.text: Simple but useful spatula for wet cleaning of the full frame DSLR camera chip. The width of spatula is designed especialy for Nikon D600 camera, but it may work for other full frame chips too or it can be narrowed by the sharp knife for the width of any smaller chip.

The spatula is pretty thin, so it is good idea to print it with the smaller layer thickness (personaly I made it with 0,2 mm).
For cleaning of the camera chip I use PecPad lint free wipes, which I cut with scisors to 4 parts (about 5 x 5 cm each). As a cleaning solution I use 99,9% clean methanol, but use of other not so dangerous but chemicaly clean alcohol (for example isoprophyl alcohol) is possible too.
I added also images of part of my camera chip before and after the cleaning by this spatula. Remark: Clean the chip of your camera only at your own risk!

Got some inspiration at the NYC 3D Printing Expo on April 22-23! Here we have generated a larger raised relief portrait of Steve using CyberExtruder's Aureus 3D Reliefmaker application. We then merged it with Thing 30973 (an iPhone 5 Case) and created this new iPhone 5 case.

Using CyberExtruder's Aureus 3D Reliefmaker application we loaded in a picture and created this 50mm tall x 10mm thick raised relief portrait. We than loaded in the Thing 30973 iPhone 5 case and aligned them as we wanted and then merged them together. The resulting .stl is just an example of some of the cool ways makers can personalize their things.

title: Traxxas Slash 4x4 LCG Dual Motor Mount

description.text:
Saw a video of a dual VXL setup, so I though I would try to make one myself. Right now it is using a single Mamba Monster 2 2650kv but I will be testing it with 2 VXL motors when i get another motor plate, and maybe 2 Mamba monsters for some even more crazy speed. This is also just a proof of concept, and ideally would be machined out of aluminum which is what is shown in the first few pictures. Uses stock mounting holes and screws, but you will need to cut out some of the plastic on the chassis for the second motor mount, as well as relocate the battery and mount the second speed controller somewhere. The second motor is attached with a second mounting plate (TRA7490) that is reverse mounted and extra screws (TRA2550 and TRA5142) and a locknut (TRA2745). Also, two shoulder screws are needed for the picot point on the motor mount (TRA3642X). MAKE SURE YOUR MOTOR SCREW IS VERY TIGHT. The MM2 likes to loosen up and strip the spur gear. Ive added a mount for the stock bearing, as well as a 10x19x5mm bearing variant. The bearing can be sourced from traxxas (TRA4889) or from here for cheaper: http://www.kingheads.com/product_info.php?products_id=934 EDIT 5/5/15: Added a slot for the screw so you can actually mount 2 motors using a reverse mount on the opposite side.
EDIT 5/16/15: Received and installed a machined aluminum version. Testing will be happening as soon so i can compare 2 vxl's to a single MM2. FINAL EDIT 6/27/15: After some testing, the dual VXL still seems less powerful than the MM2. The design works well in aluminum but it just is not as easy as a single motor. The batteries needed to be secured to the VG racing chassis brace. I used zip ties which broke on impact with a relatively small crash. The only issue I had with the dual VXL was that even after calibrating, one esc would be braking while the other was neutral throttle. Maybe this could be fixed by calibrating both at the same time? The other big difference between the dual motor vs MM2 was how much more the 2 VXLs weighed. Testing setup is as follows:
Dual VXL:
2x 5400mah 3s lipo Venom batteries in parallel
2x 19t pinion (stock 60mph+ speed pinion)
54t spur MM2:
2x 2650mah 4s lipo turnigy nano tech
13t pinion
40t spur If anyone has anymore questoins, please feel free to ask

Printed using supports and .3 mm layer height OR
CNC Machined out of aluminum

description.text:
Fits with T2.5 or GT2 belts
Hole spacing: 30mm
Upper rod belt distance: 11 mm
M3 screw for belt tension adjustment
Based on thingiverse #135353 The advantages versus a pulley-based belt tensioner are:
  • a more progressive adjustment of the tension: 1 turn of a m3 screw induces a belt extension of 1 mm for the pulley-based tensioner and 0.5 mm for this one.
  • a more stable system: for the pulley-based one, the idler pulley is "floating" and fixed for this one.

title: Case for Reprapdiscount Smart LCD Controller XXL

description.text:
This is a case for the Smart LCD Controller XXL. http://www.reprapdiscount.com/home/35-smart-lcd-controller-xxl.html
With its very big display, I think it is particularly suited to watch the printer operations from a greater distance. Maybe even using a webcam. As on my first enclosure: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:35438
I tried to design a slim enclosure again using a channel outside between the top and bottom part.
I recommend to print the parts in different colors. To be honest, otherwise it will look a little bit clumsy ;-)
I took black and green. To see how it could look like in other colors I made some variations - just photoshop :-) Instruktions
To fasten the controller board to the bottom part, first put the distance cylinders between the boards and use metrical screws M2 x 10 or tapping screws 2,2 x 10.
Both will work without tapping before.
There is no room for hexagonal pockets in the top part. You can screw M3 x 16 directly into it. And yes, don't forget to assemble the distance cylinders - the displays PCB won't like it ;-)

author: wersy

description.text:
I just created an easy way to thread Teflon (PTFE) tube.
Turn the end of a M4 ~0.7 bolt so that it fits inside the tube. thread your die onto the bolt, backward (so the taper faces out) clamp into a vise and push the tube on and hold without crushing. Now turn the tap off the bolt onto the tube gently, backing often
(Also, I will be adding my extrude design, Cog hobber and some more work on the tabloid soon.)
To use the hobbing tool, mount it as if it is a tool post, put the cog on a shaft and a coarse tap in the lathe chuck, something like 3/6 ~16 or 1/2 ~ 13, Imperial coarse tend to be bigger threads than metric of similar diameter.

title: Printable Spool End for PVC Pipe

description.text: Sides for a spool made from PVC pipe.  The inner diameter should spin cleanly around 3/4" PVC.

Print, then stick it in the end of a 2" Schedule 40 PVC pipe.  Use glue to secure it, or maybe put a screw through the pipe if you don't want it to be permanent.  
For 1kg, the pipe should be around 6" long.  This is made to print on a  150mm platform,

author: kingofbaseball

description.text: Printed on OBJET 30 at Aims Community College

Meet Scrumpty, He is the 2015 Rugby World Cup mascot for Gloucester! he has started appearing in allot of schools and museums through out the city and even has his own Facebook page. https://www.facebook.com/TheScrumptyTrail Download, Print, Enjoy! Please put up any makes, mash ups etc you produce as I would love to see them!

Support material may be required under the hands! but that should be about it.  
For reference, in the photo there is a before and after polishing of a Bronzefill Scrumpty.

Since World War II the US military has relied on the "Jeep" to get it through the mud and to the front line. There were many incarnations of it, the last being the trusty "Mutt" that was first used in Vietnam and only recently retired in the early 1990s. The U.S. Air Force used it as a mode of transport for its important forward air controllers, who helped call in pinpoint air strikes on enemy positions. My other projects:
https://myminifactory.com/object/jeep-willys-mb-3961
https://myminifactory.com/object/mini-moke-kit-car-6792

Printed at 0.2mm resolution with 10% Infill.

remixed_from.title: M3 Thumb Screw for Open-source Optics

title: M3 hex bolt press fit thumb screw

description.text:
I recently came across the Open Source Optics collection by jpearce (it's really great, you should check it out: http://www.thingiverse.com/jpearce/collections/open-source-optics), and I came across the M3 hex thumb screw on there. It seemed to me that there was no way for this to be held in place, as these nuts are rounded, and also these have to be fitted before the screw is in place. I thought I could do better, so I have designed this press fit version, which should not spin. EDIT
The original version had some bad things going on in the SketchUp file (some faces were missing/reversed). The new files should be fixed and printable now.

This piece was made using SketchUp with the InvoluteGear plugin and the ExportSTL plugin.  
I have left clearances at the outer rim of the nut and at the inner edges of the hex of 0.2Â mm, which should be sufficient - but if not, these are easily altered from the SketchUp file using Offset and Push/Pull.

title: Rapsberry Pi mount for Prusa i3 6mm Aluminium plate version

description.text:
This is a mount for the Raspberry Pi to Prusa i3 reprap printer.  
The Pi is attached to the mount with M3 screws and nuts and the mount itself then clips onto the aluminium frame of the i3.  
Network your i3 with a Raspberry Pi and Octoprint and a suitable 5v power supply. I added an L78S05CV 2A 5v fixed regulator to the RAMPS 12v supply.

Print the mount and spacers (spacers are part of the scad and the stl). Fit 2 x M3 x 12 screws into the mount so the heads are in the recess. Fit the spacers to the screws and add the Pi. Then fit M3 nuts to secure the Pi. Finally clip the legs into the i3 frame. For details of the power supply, see the data sheet for the L78S05CV regulator. It is the basic reference circuit. Input voltage from the RAMPS supply. Output connected to a micro usb lead (+5v on red, 0v on black). Regulators and datasheet available from Maplin amongst others suppliers.
http://www.maplin.co.uk/2a-positive-fixed-voltage-regulators-7939#media

Spool holder to fit the large 5kg spools with a 113mm hole
uses 608 bearings.

I printed 0.3mm 25% fill.
You may or may not need support, I used supports as it's the inner section that needs it so it doesn't slow it down much.
Need to print one for each side and each can take one or two 608 bearings. Tolerances should be fine for most but it you want to have to force the bearings in you may want to print it a tiny bit smaller.
comes with a blanking disk (608 bearing shape) if you only use one bearing per side (I've been using one per side) and a plastic washer for the nut with a slightly raised inner lip to stop it snagging on the outer edge of the bearing.
Just need some 8mm threaded bar and a few nuts as well as some sort of stand/box to support the spool.
I can print directly from the spool without issue, or you could use it to make spooling off to smaller spools easier.

description.text: Sir Squirt from Fish Center Live on Adult Swim.

This is a test of some software I wrote to convert a gray scale image to vertical profile. I drew the image in Powerpoint, made it into a 200 by 200 pixel image and then the software converted it to a "coin" and then I printed using the output stl file. I am thinking I would print a obverse and reverse separately and then glue them together back to back.  
If any of you clever coders out there want, take my source code and modify it to minimize the number of triangles by combining contiguous triangles in flat portions. I just do a dumb and simple triangulation of the pixel posts - quick and dirty but files can be large and can take a long time to process. If you add that feature, send that back to me - I would appreciate it greatly! (as you can tell I am somewhat lazy :-) )

Draw image in powerpoint or other graphics program, save it as a loss-less bitmap format (bmp, png, etc.) with resolution less than 400 x 400 pixels (square). I usually use 200 x 200 because if you use too many it just takes long to process without any improvement in printed resolution. When creating the image, remember that only the image portion in a circular region inside the square bitmap will be converted to STL. Photos may not give you the effect you want because height and grayscale are not related in photographs.   
Take the ZIP file and use visual studio C++ to build the app. I used the express version fo VS cuz it is free. The GUI is pretty simple...hit the load button and load the image file you want. Load image file into my "coin maker" and specify the coin base thickness iand the mapping from grayscale. (0-255 value) to vertical height above coin base. For example, if you say Z min is 4 and Z max is 2 then black (0) will map to a thickness of 4mm and white (255) will map to 2mm, giving a coin base that is 2mm thick and features that stick up 2mm above the coin flat surface. The software automatically masks off the image to be within a circle that touches the limits of the image, which is why I call it a "coin". It always outputs a coin that is 100mm in diameter, so you can scale it to the size you want.  
By choosing the values in the grayscale min and max and the Z min and Max you can choose how the grayscale image maps to elevations on the coin.
It's an enclosure for the USB voltage tester/capacity meter of the picture.
